awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating the relationship between rural environments characterized by industrial agriculture and the timing of puberty
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). Puberty is known to be affected by nutritional status and psychosocial stress, but less is known about the role of rural environments and, specifically, exposure to chemicals that disrupt the endocrine system. This biocultural doctoral dissertation project explores how living in rural communities shaped by industrial agriculture impacts human growth and development. The investigators compare pubertal timing in agricultural communities that have high levels of endocrine-disrupting chemical exposure to non-agricultural communities in low-exposure areas. The research contributes new knowledge about variation in patterns of human reproduction, growth, and development. The findings can inform public health policy and public science outreach.  The project includes the design of K-12 curricula on human biology and pesticides. Individuals from groups underrepresented in STEM include participants in the study as well as researchers who will be trained and mentored by the investigators.

 Endocrine-disrupting chemicals like pesticides can disrupt hormones that regulate puberty, are energetically costly to detoxify, and increase chronic disease risk in adulthood. The investigators use silicone wristbands and gas chromatography to measure exposure to endocrine-disrupting pesticides through skin or respiration among girls in communities with high and low pesticide use. The researchers evaluate and control for the roles of nutritional status, assessed using anthropometry and 24-hour dietary recalls, and psychosocial stress, measured using a variety of validated instruments. Participant observation is used to understand the local sociocultural context and differences in lived experiences between girls in the agricultural and non-agricultural communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this dissertation research is to understand how living in rural environments involved in industrial agriculture impacts the timing of puberty among girls in rural Costa Rica, with a particular interest in the impacts of exposure to pesticides applied to nearby crops. Synthetic chemicals are now found in all environments, even those without a history of industry or agriculture (e.g., artic environments have some of the highest quantities of chemicals due to global distillation). Because extensive use of synthetic chemicals is a relatively new human phenomenon and chemicals are not tested before use, we do not fully understand the effects and potential consequences of exposures, especially among females. Many pesticides have properties that can disrupt hormones, including hormones involved in puberty. Using life history theory and the exposome framework, we predicted that more exposure to pesticides would associate with earlier puberty among girls in Sarapiquí, Costa Rica due to their effects on the endocrine system. However, we also assumed girls in rural agricultural communities would experience higher rate of food insecurity and stress compared to those in non-agricultural spaces, and the combination of these environmental stressors would increase the likelihood for earlier puberty.

In 2022, the co-PI conducted interviews, surveys, and body measurements of 192 girls throughout the county of Sarapiquí, Costa Rica. We used silicone wristbands, a novel non-invasive method to capture passive measure exposure at the individual level, of which a subset was tested for chemical compounds found in various pesticides and PBDE flame retardants.  

Due to lab delays, we have not yet analyzed the relationships between the chemical exposure quantities measured by the wristbands and pubertal development. However, analyses using additional variables provide interesting results. More than half of the sample was food insecure, with the greatest insecurity found among rural, isolated, agricultural communities. Food-insecure girls consume less protein, less fiber, and less fat but more sweetened beverages, calories, and carbohydrates compared to food secure girls. Furthermore, food-insecure girls consumed more foods produced with high levels of pesticides.

The study found that girls in the late stage of puberty had the highest percentage of household members working on a farm and consumed more foods produced with high levels of pesticides, but the relationships were not significant in models using multiple variables. Breast development before age 10 years was more likely for girls that lived farther away from agriculture than those living nearby and for girls who had a serious health condition in the past. Similarly, girls who lived near a yuca plantation and had suffered from infectious disease were more likely to develop pubic hair at earlier ages. Interestingly, many variables that are usually related to puberty in Western and/or samples from developed areas with clear social stratification (e.g., weight, nutritional status, psychosocial stress, food insecurity, socioeconomic status) were not significantly associated with pubertal timing in this sample. The findings, therefore, provide a unique contrast to previous studies and propose that these factors have less impact in this context where there is little variation among the sample. Rather, it may be that cultural and peer cohesion play the greatest role.

Once the chemical data is finalized, we will be able to test whether things such as distance to agriculture and farmworkers in the household are credible predictors of pesticide exposure in this sample. We will also further explore, using advanced statistical tests, the relationships between chemical exposure and puberty.

The project contributes an exciting new addition to the methodological toolkit for human biologists and anthropologists. It is the first to use silicone wristbands to measure individual passive chemical exposure within these disciplines, to our knowledge. The preliminary data shows large variation in chemical exposure among individuals, even those living in the same neighborhoods. It contributes new insights for the use of the method to explore and explain human variation and will significantly contribute knowledge about endocrine disruption and the environmental impacts on pubertal timing.

Beyond the chemical data and analyses, the study provides insight into the lives of the people of Sarapiquí. Sarapiquí is an understudied yet highly vulnerable region. This is the only study, to our knowledge, providing data on food insecurity, nutrition, and lived experiences of the people of Sarapiquí beyond national census efforts. It has the potential to provide valuable data to the government and local authorities regarding the health and wellbeing of Sarapiquenos. Furthermore, it is the first study in Costa Rica using wristbands to measure individual exposure to chemical. Thus, this study provides concrete data on which chemicals and at what quantities are children and adolescents being exposed to-- providing important insight for policy and public health efforts in Costa Rica.
